_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Ballinger Water Treatment Plant
Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary

The City of Ballinger, Texas (City) operates the Ballinger Water Treatment Plant (Plant or WTP) which is located at 318 County Road 288 in Runnels County, Texas. The Ballinger WTP provides potable water to the City, as well as to neighboring water supply corporations. Chlorine gas is used in the disinfection process at the plant. Up to 12,000 pounds of chlorine may be stored at the Ballinger WTP. Because the stored quantity of chlorine onsite exceeds the threshold quantity for chlorine (§68.130; Table 1), the City developed this Risk Management Plan (RMP). The Ballinger WTP is subject to Program 2 RMP requirements (§68.12(c)). A Management System overseen by the WTP Superintendent is implemented to ensure that the RMP and associated Prevention Program are implemented correctly and maintained up-to-date. The City's accidental release prevention and emergency response policies include commitments to safety and to implementation of safe procedures to ensure accidental releases of chlorine gas are prevented.

The accidental release prevention program (Prevention Program) includes required elements of 40 CFR Part 68 such as safety information, hazard review, operating procedures, training, maintenance, compliance audits, and incident investigation. Detailed documentation of each element of the Prevention Program is contained within the text of the RMP. Operator training is key to the effectiveness of the Prevention Program. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) licensing program for water operators is used as a training tool, along with site-specific RMP training. TCEQ licensing testing and on-site observation and demonstration are used to evaluate comprehension of all training materials. Written operating procedures are used in conjunction with on-the-job training to ensure that certified WTP operators are proficient in performing their duties before being allowed to work with c

hlorine storage and feed systems. Certified WTP operators conduct daily inspections and any problems with the chlorine systems are corrected and documented. In addition, the certified WTP operators ensure that the equipment used in the disinfection process is maintained according to the manufacturers' recommendations (§68.56(a)). Because of these efforts, the WTP has not had a chlorine release that resulted in an injury, either on-site or off-site, within the previous five (5) years (§68.42(a)). As part of the Prevention Program, the City will periodically perform compliance audits, hazard reviews, and incident investigations, according to a predetermined schedule described in the RMP and as needs dictate. These compliance audits and hazard reviews document any planned changes to improve safety (§68.50 & §68.58).

The Ballinger WTP complies with the emergency response regulations per Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 29 CFR §1910.38, as well as with applicable standards set forth by the Chlorine Institute and the Texas Administrative Code. The Ballinger WTP is a non-responding facility for emergency response. The WTP is located outside the city limits in Runnels County. The Ballinger WTP is included in the Runnels County Emergency Response Plan. Coordination activities are conducted in accordance with §68.93 with the first responders [the City of Ballinger Volunteer Fire Department (VFD)] and Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) (the county judge or designee) at least annually, and more frequently if necessary. WTP operators are trained to contact the Runnels County dispatch via 911 in the event of a release.  The Runnels County dispatch contacts the nearest first responder unit (typically the City of Ballinger VFD) which coordinates the emergency response according to the county Emergency Response Plan, including the evacuation of surrounding residents when required (§68.90(b)).
